# Punjab and Haryana High Court

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

    _" Punjab High Court" redirects here. For the high court in Pakistan, see [Lahore High Court](/wiki/Lahore_High_Court "Lahore High Court")._
Punjab and Haryana High Court  
---  
[![Capitol High
Court.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Capitol_High_Court.jpg/225px-
Capitol_High_Court.jpg)](/wiki/File:Capitol_High_Court.jpg) High Court
building  
Established | 1919, relocated in 1947  
Country | India  
Location | [Sector 1, Chandigarh](/w/index.php?title=Sector_1,_Chandigarh&action=edit&redlink=1 "Sector 1, Chandigarh \(page does not exist\)")  
Authorized by | [Constitution of India](/wiki/Constitution_of_India "Constitution of India")  
[Decisions are appealed to](/wiki/Appeal "Appeal") | [Supreme Court of India](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_India "Supreme Court of India")  
Judge term length | mandatory retirement by age of 62  
No. of positions | 88 (67 permanent, 21 additional)  
Website | <http://www.highcourtchd.gov.in/>  
[Chief Justice](/wiki/Chief_Justice "Chief Justice")  
Currently | Mr. Krishna Murari  
  
**High Court of Punjab and Haryana** is the common [High
Court](/wiki/High_courts_in_india "High courts in india") for Indian states of
[Haryana](/wiki/Haryana "Haryana") and [Punjab](/wiki/Punjab,_India "Punjab,
India") and Union Territory of [Chandigarh](/wiki/Chandigarh "Chandigarh")
based in [Chandigarh](/wiki/Chandigarh "Chandigarh"), India. As of 21 March
2015, there are 55 judges in the High Court, comprising 45 permanent and 10
additional judges. Past judges include Jagdish Singh Khehar, who was elevated
to the [Supreme Court of India](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_India "Supreme Court of
India").[1][2][3]

The court building is known as the **Palace of Justice**. Designed by Le
Corbusier, it and several of his other works were inscribed as [UNESCO World
Heritage Sites](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") in July
2016.[4][5]

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Punjab_and_Haryana_High_Court&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

Punjab and Haryana High Court was formerly known as [Lahore](/wiki/Lahore
"Lahore") High Court, which was established on 21 March 1919. The jurisdiction
of that court covered [undivided Punjab](/wiki/Punjab_region "Punjab region")
and [Delhi](/wiki/Delhi "Delhi"). From 1920 to 1943, the Court was conferred
with [extraterritorial jurisdiction](/wiki/Extraterritorial_jurisdiction
"Extraterritorial jurisdiction") over that part of [China](/wiki/China
"China") that formed part of the British consular district of
[Kashgar](/wiki/Kashgar "Kashgar"), which had previously been under the
jurisdiction of the [British Supreme Court for
China](/wiki/British_Supreme_Court_for_China "British Supreme Court for
China").[6] This ceased upon the ratification of the [British-Chinese Treaty
for the Relinquishment of Extra-Territorial Rights in China](/wiki/British-
Chinese_Treaty_for_the_Relinquishment_of_Extra-Territorial_Rights_in_China
"British-Chinese Treaty for the Relinquishment of Extra-Territorial Rights in
China").[7]

Following the [independence of India](/wiki/Independence_of_India
"Independence of India") on 15 August 1947, a separate High Court of Punjab
was created, based at [Shimla](/wiki/Shimla "Shimla"). This had jurisdiction
over [Indian Punjab](/wiki/Punjab,_India "Punjab, India"), Delhi and what are
now [Himachal Pradesh](/wiki/Himachal_Pradesh "Himachal Pradesh") and Haryana.
From 17 January 1955, the Court was moved to its present location in
Chandigarh.

The creation of Himachal Pradesh on 15 August 1948 led to a separate Court of
Judicial Commissioner (similar to a High Court) being established for that
state and thus the jurisdiction of the Punjab court was reduced. A separate
High Court was constituted for the [Union Territory of
Delhi](/wiki/Union_Territory_of_Delhi "Union Territory of Delhi") under the
_Delhi High Court Act, 1966_.[8] Three Judges of the Punjab High Court were
transferred to the [Delhi High Court](/wiki/Delhi_High_Court "Delhi High
Court"), which was constituted on 31 October 1966.

The _[States Reorganisation Act, 1956](/wiki/States_Reorganisation_Act,_1956
"States Reorganisation Act, 1956")_ paved the way for the formation of Haryana
and the Union Territory of Chandigarh from 1 November 1966. Those formations
also saw the renaming of the High Court of Punjab as the High Court of Punjab
and Haryana. The Judges of the High Court of Punjab became Judges of the
common High Court with all the powers and jurisdiction of the High Court of
Punjab. However, the principal seat of the High Court remained at Chandigarh.

The High Court of Punjab and Haryana has operated since 1 November 1966 in its
present form.
